name: Santander
fun_fact: Fun fact: Santander sits on the Bay of Biscay in Cantabria, where the mountains literally meet the sea - you can ski in the morning at Picos de Europa and eat fresh seafood on the beach by lunch.

hero_dishes.origin_story: Rabas are Santander's beloved pre-Sunday lunch tradition. Locals order them before family meals, especially when accompanied by a glass of Vermouth. hero_dishes.description: Hearty mountain stew with white beans, pork (bacon, ribs, chorizo), and leafy greens like cabbage or kale
hero_dishes.origin_story: This 'mountain stew' originated as fuel for workers in Cantabria's Picos de Europa mountains. Using leftover pork, especially the rich fatty cuts, with local white beans creates a deeply satisfying stew. It's mountain food - designed to provide calories for physical labor in cold weather. Now it's regional pride.

hero_dishes.origin_story: Santander's fishing district pulls seafood directly from the Bay of Biscay's cold, nutrient-rich waters. The freshness is incomparable - restaurants like Casa Jos√© in the fishing district serve what arrived hours earlier. Cantabrians trust the catch so much they often prepare it simply.

hero_dishes.name: Cantabrian Pinchos
hero_dishes.description: Northern Spanish small bites - the Cantabrian version of Basque pintxos, creative and abundant
hero_dishes.origin_story: While Basque Country gets fame for pintxos, Santander has its own pincho culture. Casa Lita serves approximately 300 different types made fresh daily. The tradition of hopping between bars for different pinchos (pincho crawl) is evening entertainment.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Casa Lita (huge array of northern Spanish pinchos - 300 types made daily with quality produce), tapas bars throughout the city

signature_drinks.name: Vermouth
signature_drinks.description: Aromatized fortified wine, often served on tap, popular before Sunday lunch
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The pre-Sunday lunch ritual pairs vermouth with rabas. Served over ice with an olive or orange peel, it's aperitif culture - stimulating appetite while socializing. Cantabrians take their vermouth traditions seriously.

signature_drinks.name: Orujo
signature_drinks.description: Pomace brandy from grape skins, Cantabria's digestif - clear and potent
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served after heavy meals like cocido monta√±√©s. Some versions are flavored with herbs or coffee. It's strong (40%+) and considered essential for digestion after rich mountain stews.
